'Laurence Kerr Olivier, Baron Olivier', OM (; 22 May 190711 July
1989) was a British actor, director, and producer. An Anglican clergyman's son,
Olivier became determined early on to master Shakespeare, and eventually came to
be regarded as one of the foremost Shakespeare interpreters of the 20th
century. Hodgdon, Barbara. Shakespeare Quarterly, "From the Editor", Fall,
2002

His three Shakespeare films as actor-director, [[Henry V (1944 film)|Henry V]]
(1944), [[Hamlet (1948 film)|Hamlet]] (1948), and [[Richard III (1955
film)|Richard III]] (1955), are among the pinnacles of the bard at the cinema.
Olivier was the youngest actor to be knighted as a Knight Bachelor, in 1947, and
the first to be elevated to the peerage two decades later.

During a six-decade career, Olivier played many other roles on stage and screen.
On stage his more than 120 roles included Richard III, Macbeth, Romeo, Hamlet,
Uncle Vanya, and Archie Rice in [[The Entertainer (play)|The Entertainer]]. He
appeared in nearly sixty films, including William Wyler's [[Wuthering Heights
(1939 film)|Wuthering Heights]] (1939), Alfred Hitchcock's [[Rebecca (1940
film)|Rebecca]] (1940), Stanley Kubrick's [[Spartacus (film)|Spartacus]] (1960),
and Joseph L. Mankiewicz's [[Sleuth (1972 film)|Sleuth]] (1972). His other
Shakespeare roles for the cinema were as Orlando in [[As You Like It (1936
film)|As You Like It]] (1936) and the lead in [[Othello (1965 film)|Othello]]
(1965), with virtually the entire cast from the production at the Old Vic of the
National Theatre Company, of which he was then artistic director. He had earlier
filled the same post at the Old Vic after the Second World War. The largest
stage in the National Theatre building was later named after him.

Olivier retired from the stage in 1973, but his work on-screen continued until
the year before his death in 1989. For television,
he starred in [[Long Day's Journey into Night]] (1973), [[The Merchant of
Venice]] (1973), [[Cat on a Hot Tin Roof]] (1976), [[Brideshead Revisited (TV
serial)|Brideshead Revisited]] (1981), and [[King Lear (1983 TV drama)|King
Lear]] (1983), among others. His later films for cinema included John
Schlesinger's [[Marathon Man (film)|Marathon Man]] (1976) and Richard
Attenborough's [[A Bridge Too Far (film)|A Bridge Too Far]] (1977).

Actor Spencer Tracy stated that Olivier was "the greatest actor in the English-
speaking world", Tracy quoted in By Myself and Then Some by Lauren Bacall.
Harper Paperbacks: 2006. pp. 214-15. and film critic Barry Norman regarded
Olivier as "the finest actor I have ever seen or probably will ever
see." Director Jonathan Miller (who directed Olivier in The Merchant
of Venice) warned: "I hope that no actor tries to copy him." Olivier's AMPAS acknowledgments are considerable: twelve Oscar
nominations, with two awards (for Best Actor and Best Picture for the 1948 film
[[Hamlet (1948 film)|Hamlet]]), plus two honorary awards including a statuette
and certificate. He was also awarded five Emmy awards from the nine nominations
he received. Additionally, he was a three-time Golden Globe and BAFTA winner.

He married three times, to actresses Jill Esmond, Vivien Leigh, and Joan
Plowright, his widow.
